and then we have a couple special guests a few of our partners are here and gonna give some use case talks we have rich
for Waller from Symantec and the Lima Rastogi from the mist oh
cool so I'll jump right in here I'm here to talk about AWS security hub I'm going to
talk a little bit about the service what it does the benefits the rollout that we had yesterday
Jackson do a quick demo we're going to talk about those partner use cases and then give you a heads up about how you
can get started hopefully we'll have a few a few minutes for questions at the end but to jump into the service I first
wanted to set some context this is folks may be familiar with this this is the
NIST cybersecurity framework and this is really how AWS security thinks about our
security services and how we organize them the five function framework begins
with identify this is about identifying your assets identifying your risks and
identifying your assets and risks are of course the most important step to starting your security process you need to understand what's in your
organization before you secure your organization we have tools like config and Systems Manager to help with that
inventory of resources next you have protect protect it's all about putting
that hard outer shell around your people your resources your applications and your data we have services like laugh
and shield kms I am acceptor etcetera and then next we have detect and respond
in the detection piece we have new services like guard duty paella folks
know guard duty it's become one of the fastest-growing services in AWS but before we get to respond there's
actually two different ways you can get to respond this is an AWS addition to the NIST cybersecurity framework in
general folks want to automate response as much I'll do that with lambda functions do that with step functions but there's
usually some security issues and compliance issues left over that need a human touch from human review so we
provide investigation services like cloud trail and cloud watch to help with that lastly recover recovery in AWS is a
lot easier than doing it on Prem while I was in government's you know if we had an advanced intruder in our networks
usually you're throwing away hardware you're burning down networks and at AWS you're simply reverting to snapshots and
gold the images and can recover much much much more quickly all right so with
that with context why do we build AWS security hub there are really four
problems that it'll be a security hub addresses the first one is that many
customers that are adopting AWS have various compliance requirements either
internal requirements or external regulatory requirements and we want to make it easier for them to meet them
oftentimes as new companies are adopting cloud for the first time really they
want to make sure that they're setting up their environments correctly and compliance checks can really help with that
secondly and the second problem actually is an AWS unique problem this is probably clickable to any security
organization whether you're using AWS or not but typically you have dozens of different security tools those security
tools need to be integrated oftentimes you're spending hundreds even thousands of hours parsing and normalizing data to
get into a common format so that you can do search and analysis on it thirdly we
have customers that have only a few different security alerts that they have to deal with a day we have customers
that are dealing with tens of thousands of security alerts per day obviously as you get to those higher numbers it's
much more than what a human can process so you need tools to better prioritize
those and really understand what are the most important security compliance issues that you need to address and then
lastly customers want that coveted single pane of glass for security compliance issues they want
one place they can go to each day to better understand their security and compliance state and this is this is why
we built security hub so security hub it really begins with a simple and easy
getting started process really with just a couple of clicks you get started and
we start ingesting data we start to conducting compliance checks and it's
actually the same setup and start process as guard duty for folks that are familiar with that once you have turned
on security hub with those few clicks we start ingesting data we've done fully
automated integrations with our core security services like guard duty mason inspector and we've integrated with 29
additional partner products for this for this initial launch now all those
different security services both ours and partners have normalized their data
into a common format which we call the AWS finding format this means that you
can simply turn on the service turn on any of the partner integrations and all that data is ready for analysis from the
get-go no parsing or normalization needed huge pain point that we've solved
with security hub we've also developed these lightweight correlation rules called insights that allow you to
correlate different types of alerts and security issues together to identify which of your resources are most
problematic and which ones you need to focus on remediation simultaneously you
were doing automated compliance checks so we're running continuous compliance checks in the background and also
producing new findings that flag whether there are account level issues that you
need to remediated any of the accounts that you've integrated with security hub and then lastly we're not just a
visualization tool we help you close that loop and allow you to take action on those most important findings we do
this via cloud watch events and we've actually already released some integrations with incident management tools chat systems and remediation
platforms so specifically yesterday morning
Andy Jesse announced security hub coming out as public preview what that means is
that it's actually free for everyone the only exception is there is a dependency on AWS config so if you're not running
config yet you do need to turn that on there's no charge for the config rules that we use for our compliance checks
but there is an additional charge for config items if you're not are using config it's open to everyone
no white listing or gating needed and we'll turn this into a generally available service once we iterate on
some customer feedback from you all there is full API CLI and SDK support
and we're not gonna be doing any backwards breaking changes so you can go ahead and start using those today to
build out any additional custom integrations and we're launching at a global scale so we launched in 15
regions around the world yesterday today security hub is a multi counts single
region service so you do need to turn on and you need to have separate instances in each region and then the future we'll
move this to a full multi account multi-region service alright so partner
integrations this is actually probably something I've most proud about this launch we really built a great community
during this initial build-out process we have 29 different partner integrations
from 24 different companies you can see that some of the companies actually build multiple integrations like Splunk
Wallis Palo Alto and checkpoint all of
these integrations are fully integrated with the AWS finding format so when you
turn on these integrations these partners they're pushing their data re parsed normalized into that aff format
and you know one of the things that I thought was really really cool about
this whole process was these partners came together in a really amazing and
inspirational manner we were crashing hard as we were to hit the reinvent deadline we actually
didn't push the final code to partners until November 16th and over the course
of a week over Thanksgiving all 29 of these product integrations were
finalized completed and fully validated by AWS most of them were demoed in
customer environments all the others were demoed in our own account and amazing thing happened as we're going
through that final push we've set up a slack channel so partners could ask questions to us about the
technical integrations and partners actually start helping each other there was really no economic incentive
for partners to help each other but you know I think it really reflected what
we're trying to do with this product in establish a community and there was a level of kindness and empathy and
generosity that you don't see enough inside the secured community and I thought was really cool and I wanted to
flag that all right so in reality every
partner on here deserves a slide probably need a whole separate

these three that my flag necks I think are particularly interesting and worth worth of notation first CrowdStrike
so CrowdStrike has built a Python app that deploys into into your environments
that Python app collects findings from all the instances where the CrowdStrike
agent is deployed it takes those findings translates them into the AWS
finding format and then they do this really cool process where they actually query the AWS API further enrich those
findings and then transfer them into the alw security hub with that initial
enriched information they have a cloud formation template where you can get up
and running with this integration in under 15 minutes
next alert logic alert logic is the MSSP the thing that I really love about the
alert logic integration is that they - an amazing job of reducing the customer
noise or reducing the noise around security findings and security alerts what they do is that they take findings
from all your different security tools and then they do additional processing and analysis on those findings and then
they only push to security hub the confirmed findings that are issues the true positives and the incidents that
they have confirmed indeed need your attention so they do a great job reducing the noise and then pushing -
security hub only the truly important things there integration as soon as you
click Subscribe in the AWS provider page within the security up console
automatically you'll start pushing findings to secure hub from earlier logic last partner example are burn
another MSSP the thing that I love about the armorer integration is how easy and
simple it is to get started they have a toggle switch in their UI flip that
toggle and all the permissions cross account roles are put in place and you're automatically integrated with AWS
security hub and then they actually have additional capability where you can select the specific data sets that you
want push the security hub which gives the user some finer grained control of what exactly they want to see in their
dashboards all right so next I'm going
to jump into a quick run-through of some of the core features of AWS security hub
first the multi account setup so for folks that are familiar with guard duty
this will look very very similar in fact it is essentially the same code and the
process for multi account setup is that you identify whether you want to
designate an account as the master account and then you're able to invite
member accounts to that master you simply up load a CSV file of account numbers and
email addresses associate that account or you can manually type them in and all of those member accounts will then get
invitation to join you as a master once they hit accept that master account will
see all of the findings the security compliance findings for all those member accounts so we're doing this multi
account roll-up so as the master account you can really see everything across all your accounts member accounts will only
be able to see their findings their own findings inside their own account
alright next compliance checks so the first compliance module that
we've rolled out is the Center for Internet Security AWS foundations benchmark this consists of 43 fully
automated continuous compliance checks and these are looking for account level
configuration issues whether you have proper password policies in place whether you've configured cloud trail
correctly whether you're rotating your keys whether you've using your route account properly so these are
continuously running in the background and we do a nice job of rolling these up into Dashboard widgets so that you can
quickly see which of those 43 rules have a compliant versus non-compliant status
if any of the rules have a single failed or warning status across any of the
accounts that entire rule comes back has failed I'm sorry that tie rule comes back it's non-compliant next insights so
insights are those lightweight correlation rules we've prepackaged the
system with over 25 insights and I have a really really simple example here this
insight you can see the definition of it in the filter here it's simply looking for current findings or active findings
and then it's doing the aggregation by a mi name so what this allows you to do is
quickly see which am is our most problematic you know which ones have the most
security and compliance findings associated with it but this can really also just be a starting point you can
easily add additional filters as an example you might want to add additional filters to look at a.m. eyes that are in
your production environments and they're down to that you can also do an
statements so if you want to see a.m. eyes that have vulnerabilities and
suspicious behaviors such as tactics techniques and procedures associates are
adversaries you can build filters like that and as you can see you don't have to learn new query language for this
this can all be done visually it can also be done programmatically through our API but it's really designed for an
analyst to get started real quick and we're giving folks number of starting points to do so we roll up a number of
these insights into a summary dashboard so line charts stack bar charts bar charts etc to help
an analyst understand you know what are the things they need to focus on each day all right
we're not just a visualization tool so we are also helping you close the loop
and take action on those high priority high severity compliance and security
issues we do this via cloud watch events and this is highly configurable we have
some sample code for integrations with tools like page or duty and slack
sending to email via SNS but you can very easily create your own custom
actions but as analysts as I'm going through my process of alert triage and
figuring out what are the security compliance findings that I need to pay attention to I may identify one and then
I can flag that one and send it out for action sent out to a ticketing system to a chat system to a remediation platform
etc when I take that action that finding or collection of findings is emitted
from the security hub tool as a cloud watch event it's decorated with a custom
action ID and then there will be a corresponding rule in cloud watch events in the cloud watch console that picks up
that custom action ID and matches it to the rule and sends it to a designated target
that target is usually either a lambda function or step function that lambda
function may chop up that date a little bit further and then push it to its final destination which could be slack
could be G or pedra duty could also be a WS arrow this is a really cool
professional service offering if folks haven't heard about it there are 25 different remediation packages that and
will actually showcase a few of those in the demo all right speaking of which

felt I really felt bad for the team I think some of the team members are in here so I'm gonna send you some chocolates for Christmas but the the
scenario was kind of walking left to right here was they were using guard duty and they were using guard duty as
kind of like I describe it as a canary they were using guard duty to identify kind of suspicious behavior but because
of the industry that LifeLock was in they had to be 100% sure that anything
suspicious didn't mean a compromised so the findings that they were getting a
lot of were the the port scans in the brute force login attempts and so what
the process was is guard duty would kick off a finding to them they take that to their log aggregation service and the
volume of that those types of findings were just so large that they literally had to dedicate time to go in and do
some investigation on ok does this mean anything what is this what does this mean so the scenario would be that get a
finding you go to their log aggregation they would log in to see WP my product and they were using C WP mostly from a
file integrity monitoring use case so they would correlate those events and they would look at that and if that was
okay like if they went in there and they looked at those events and they're like yeah this doesn't look like it compromised anything they kind of sign
off on that but if they're if there was inadequate information there or there was something suspicious they would have
to kind of pass this over to a remediation step and all of this was manual and this is why these guys hate me and I owe them box of chocolates so
they would pass this over to a manual process and they would execute like scans or some of the further analysis
that we would do and then if that went away again they said okay we're good to go we can go ahead and close this case
but it would be a process of back and forth until they kind of get got to a level of where the findings had either
stopped or that they had sufficient data that this didn't mean anything so we were actually down a development path to
fix this and we were looking you know how do we better integrate with guard duty when Eli's team called out to
us and said hey we're looking at launching a service it'll be a central point for all security events in AWS
it'll have this format that you can follow and I literally felt like reaching through the chyme telephone and
kissing him on his bearded chiseled face it was just like that's awesome I'm on so this is the kind of process
that we went from there so what we did was we continued with guard duty they continue to use that and it's still kind
of a canary service for them they're the turning on atw security have just like Eli mentioned it's it's very very easy

on the volume that would kick off a process to CWP to do one of two things it would either take events around that
time frame associated to those instances and put those back to the security hub
so they could correlate that or it would actually start to execute automatically some of those steps so if again if it
